block.p: Israeli planes and artillery hammered Lebanon for the fifth day, but Israeli and American officials said intensive contacts had begun in an effort to end the fighting. A1
Some 400,000 Lebanese remain displaced by the attacks. A12
Israel will allow a guerrilla leader into Palestinian-ruled areas. A12
In a project reminiscent of the chilliest days of the cold war, Russia is building a mammoth underground military complex in the Ural Mountains, officials say. A1
South Africa's Truth Commission began its work of trying to put the past to rest by inviting a half dozen victims of apartheid's brutality to tell their stories. A3
Liberian leaders tried to shore up a tenuous truce even as sporadic sniper fire rang out the capital and young thugs raced through the streets with assault rifles. A3 ROLLING IN THE MILLENNIUM
London is preparing to construct a 500-foot-tall ferris wheel -- the largest in the world -- that would rotate continuously on the south bank of the Thames in celebration of the millennium.A7
ACCORD ON U.S. BASES IN JAPAN
The United States and Japan agreed on a plan to reduce the friction caused by the American bases in Okinawa, raising questions about future relations. A8
Nairobi Journal: The politics of minibuses in Kenya. A4
Republican leaders in Congress introduced counterterrorism legislation and predicted that it would be approved by the anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing. A1 INVENTORY TAKEN AT CABIN
A Federal inventory said agents searching Theodore Kaczynski's Montana cabin had found a wealth of evidence. A1
A Florida university rescheduled exams after a bomb threat. A19
The Environmental Protection Agency is proposing changes in how it determines which chemicals and pollutants cause cancer, relying less on animal tests. A1
At a time when Congress has been overhauling agricultural subsidies, the subsidies that support the production of ethanol have remained untouched, largely through the efforts of Bob Dole. A1
The boy whose record Jessica Dubroff was trying to break when her plane crashed and other young pilots are being scrutinized in a way they never were before. A14
Jessica Dubroff's funeral was held in Pescadero, Calif. A14

Trying to entice people to live in the District of Columbia, Representative Eleanor Holmes Norton introduced legislation that would cut the top rate of Federal income tax to 15 percent for District residents. A14

Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, frustrated at not being able to extend the life of the special inquiry into the Whitewater affair, began plans to hold hearings on the subject before the Senate Banking Committee. A15
The Supreme Court considered whether political parties have a constitutional right to spend unlimited amounts of money to get across their candidates' messages. A17
The House rejected the proposed Republican Constitutional amendment to require two-thirds majorities to raise Federal taxes. A18

A legal group founded by the National Rifle Association gave $20,000 for the defense of Bernhard H. Goetz, who is being sued by a man who was left paralyzed after Mr. Goetz shot him in a Manhattan subway 12 years ago. A1
Treasures of Troy goes on view in Moscow. C11
Television: "Terror in the Family." C16 Fashion B8
Of acorns, mice, Lyme disease and gypsy moths. C1
The optimal dose of vitamin C may be triple the current R.D.A. C1
Juggling numbers to understand the patterns of juggling. C1
Acid rain tied to a starving forest. C4
Combination of drugs approved for ulcers. C5
What is consciousness? A contentious jury can't decide. C9
Basketball: Johnson is suspended and fined. B9
Knicks beat Raptors, but learn Oakley is out for the season. B9
Columns: Araton on the Boston Marathon. B9
Marathon: Kenyans dominate in Boston. B9
Letters Russell Baker: George in Heaven.
A. M. Rosenthal: The winner in Lebanon.
Richard N. Haass: A new Japan policy?
Peter Kornbluh: The C.I.A.'s Cuban cover-up.
